   java.lang.AssertionError
    at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:86)
    at org.junit.Assert.assertTrue(Assert.java:41)
    at org.junit.Assert.assertTrue(Assert.java:52)
    at gobblin.source.extractor.extract.google.webmaster.GoogleWebmasterExtractorIteratorTest.testIterator(GoogleWebmasterExtractorIteratorTest.java:79)

Hi Chavdar,

The unit test failure was caused by a non-determined order of HashMap
values. I've fixed the failure by adding a customized Matcher for
CollectionEquals.

class CollectionEquals extends ArgumentMatcher<Collection> {

  private final Collection _expected;

  public CollectionEquals(Collection expected) {
    _expected = expected;
  }

  @Override
  public boolean matches(Object actual) {
    return CollectionUtils.isEqualCollection((Collection) actual, _expected);
  }
}

It took me a while to figure out how to fix this. I feel like other people
may experience the same issue. So this could be moved to a better place.

Thanks,
Chen

I couldn't find documentation around port = -1, but creating a TestServer without specifying any port number seems to create a Zookeeper with random port: http://netflix.github.io/curator/doc/com/netflix/curator/test/TestingServer.html#TestingServer() 

However, we will have to check that if the random port which TestingServer decides to use is already bound, then does: 
- TestingServer fails (thus causing potentially flaky intermittently failing tests)
- OR, TestingServer tries to fallback to another random port

I found the behavior by looking at the code. Internally, using new TestingServer(-1), uses new ServerSocket(0) to allocate an available port. There is a small race condition between we find the port and the time it is used by ZK but there is not much we can do about it.

1. ReplicationDataRetentionCategory specify whether the copy is "Sync", "limited snapshots copy", "limited daily partitions copy" or "limited hourly partitions copy"
2. ReplicationDataValidPathPicker will use GlobModTimeDatasetVersionFinder or DateTimeDatasetVersionFinder to find the valid paths to copy from source to target

High-level summary of changes: 

1) A top-level directory called gobblin-modules which will be used to store any datasystem specific integrations such as kafka. 
2) gobblin-modules/gobblin-kafka-common: a module that contains classes that are related to Kafka integration but do not depend on Kafka. 
3) gobblin-modules/gobblin-kafka-08: classes that allow reading, writing to Kafka 0.8 and reporting metrics to Kafka 0.8
4) gobblin-modules/gobblin-kafka-09: future home of readers, writers, reporters for Kafka 0.9. Currently only hosts the KafkaWriter.
5) gobblin-core-base: datasystem independent classes extracted from gobblin-core that help in creating datasystem integrations
6) gobblin-metrics : slimmed down and no longer depends on kafka or bundles the kafka reporter
7) gobblin-core: to preserve backwards compatibility, pulls in gobblin-kafka-08 using the standard flavored build for gobblin. This module can only depend on either gobblin-kafka-08 or gobblin-kafka-09. This can be controlled through the -DgobblinFlavor build argument and the respective gradle file (e.g. gobblin-core/gobblin-flavor-standard.gradle, gobblin-core/gobblin-flavor-full.gradle, ..)
@abti : What better time to check in massive changes than Fri midnight?

We seem to have accumulated quite a few different converters for doing field level operations on records. Instead of chaining these converters by hand and specifying config independently for each, maybe we should have an uber converter for supporting config-driven transformation of the record.

@chavdar can you review?

It seems it's following the pattern on how it was done with SpeculativeAttemptAwareConstruct. Code itself looks correct, but I am afraid it would keep fanning out. 
@chavdar Do you think it would make sense to introduce an abstract class to DataWriter that returns defaults?
@jinhyukchang I don't think I understand you comment about fanning out.

@chavdar What I meant was, we would need to add more methods like this change in the future. For that case, how about introducing abstract class (e.g: AbstractDecoratedDataWriter) that provides default behavior? As you can see from this PR change in RetryWriter and ThrottleWriter are the same.
I see that makes sense.
@enjoyear google-ingestion/ is a bit too generic a name. As @shirshanka suggested, google-webmaster or google-source-webmaster are more descriptive.
@chavdar this is just a beginning. You just see gobblin.ingestion.google.webmaster for now. There are more coming. For example, the next one is gobblin.ingestion.google.adwords.
I see. Do they share code/libraries? If yes, it makes sense to keep them in the same module.
@chavdar Actually, only the credential/login part share quite similar code. The rest of the code depends on different APIs/jars provided by google.

@chavdar By the way, the code under gobblin-core/src/main/java/gobblin/source/extractor/extract/google should be moved under this google-ingestion module as well. Ideally, this refactoring can start after this pull request is finished.
YEs, we are in the process of refactoring the code and taking dependencies out.
